title: What is a Tree?
contentText: A tree is a hierarchical data structure represented by nodes and the edges connecting them. It starts from a root node and expands through child nodes. A tree is commonly visualized like an upside-down tree.

title: Tree Structure and Properties
contentText: A tree has a single root node, and each node may have one or more children. The relationship between nodes is defined as parent-child. Every node except the root has exactly one parent.

title: Types of Trees
contentText: Binary Tree: Each node has at most two children. AVL Tree: A self-balancing binary search tree. K-ary Tree: Each node can have up to K children. B-Tree: A balanced tree used in databases and file systems.

title: Tree Use Cases
contentText: Trees are used in database indexing, file system organization, expression parsing, and decision-making algorithms in AI.

title: Advantages of Trees
contentText: Trees provide efficient search, insertion, and deletion for many scenarios. They represent hierarchical relationships naturally and support scalable data organization.

title: Example Applications
contentText: Examples include website navigation structures, organization charts, and category hierarchies in e-commerce systems.
